awd_titl_txt: Scholarships for Robotics and Mechatronics Systems Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to address the increasing demand for engineers who need to be trained for multi-disciplinary product innovation, University of Detroit Mercy (UDM) launched a new undergraduate degree program entitled "Robotics and Mechatronic Systems Engineering."  The objectives of this proposed S-STEM project is to attract talented students, particularly women and minorities, into this new program and increase the number of engineering graduates trained in interdisciplinary engineering through financial help, mentoring, improved student support, and retention efforts.  The long-term strategy includes several components: (a) working with the extensive pre-college program that the college already sponsors to increase the interest of students in engineering disciplines, (b) working with high schools, For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST) Robotics Competition teams and community colleges to attract more students into engineering disciplines, and (c) provide scholarships and academic support to qualified and financially challenged students who enroll in this new degree program.

The project has an aggressive retention plan including:  strong academic support for the S-STEM scholars with comprehensive, focused, and cohort-based advising; cohort-based registration in most classes to help develop camaraderie within the group; tutoring in math and other challenging subjects, as needed; participation of all S-STEM students in a one-year paid co-op experience in industry; mentoring from alumni and industry leaders on the college advisory board; annual field trips and networking events to develop professional relationships with potential employers and develop career insights.  This project will help develop the understanding of the effect of early cohort formation and mentoring on college success, enable formation of closer ties with specific industrial partners through the expansion of the co-op program, and improve the student support structure at UDM through evidence-based techniques of academic intervention.  This project will also help establish a committed group of alumni from the new degree program who will make the program stronger for future generations of engineers.  The results from this program will be presented at educational conferences such as American Society for Engineering Education Annual conference and the Frontiers in Engineering Education conference.

por.por_cntn:
In 2012 University of Detroit Mercy launched a new undergraduate major in Robotics and Mechatronics Systems Engineering (RMSE).   This was one of the earliest such inter-disciplinary major in the state.  The program achieved ABET accreditation in 2016.   This S-STEM grant, approved in 2015, was meant for providing scholarship support to 16 students for four years to help them earn a Bachelor's degree in this new major.   At Detroit Mercy, the students were supported by various offices at the university to help them finish their program and earn a degree.   All the students, by the time they graduated, completed three paid-engineering-internships in industry.

When this proposal was written and funded, the RMSE program was very new on our campus  The S-STEM scholarship helped significantly to attract and retain students in the program who might have otherwise gone for a more traditional engineering discipline.  It also helped build up the critical mass of students in the major when the major  was relatively unknown to students and employers.   During the life-time of this grant the industrial world changed significantly.   Automotive industry, the main employer of our students have taken a strategic decision to replace their internal combustion engine-based vehicles with electric fleets.   Awareness of the environmental impact of fossil fuels has increased a lot and there is concerted effort to use an interdiscipllinary approach to devise technological solutions to address climate change.   Autonomous vehicles are starting to become a reality too.  The same employers who had to be courted to consider hiring students from this new major are now naturally gravitating towards them.  Also, this has now become the more popular major among new students as employers recognize the strong need for students trained in this multi-disciplinary topic.  

In the original grant, the plan was to financially support 16 students for four years.  Between the NSF scholarship and the university-provided scholarship, tuition for all the students in the program became fully covered.   In order to meet the project goals, we eventually recruited 19 students into the program.  Of these 19, three students dropped out after their respective first year of college due to poor academic performance.  Of the rest, eight have graduated and are working full-time.  Five students work in General Motors, two in Ford and one in Stellantis (formerly, Chrysler).   Almost all of the remaining students are on-track to graduate in 2023.  Three students were inducted into TBP (Engineering Honor Society) and one of them served as the TBP student chapter president for two years.   Two students opted to complete a Master's degree through the Detroit Mercy 5-yr Master's program.

Of the 12 male and 7 female students who were recruited in the program there were 5 African American students, 5 Hispanic students, and 11 students were 1st generation students.  Four male and four female students have graduated and are working full-time in engineering jobs.  They have all accepted very high quality job offers in the automotive big-three of Detroit.   All these companies have elite rotation programs for sought-after new recruits.  Almost all of our students are in these programs within their organizations.  They are also unique ambassadors for the university and this new major and will help us in future to recruit more student, and host and mentor the next genertion of students as interns within their corporations.   

More than 50% of the students who were recruited in this program were 1st generation college students.   For this sub-group, going to college, graduating, and being gainfully employed is having a significant positive impact on their family and is expected to impact their future generations financially and culturally.  

Grants such as this one are designed to impact the lives of individuals, their family, and through them, the larger community and society in general.   Students graduating with significant NSF support in a nascent yet thriving discipline are destined to become leaders of tomorrow within their field.   They will be the catalysts that transform their family, their own future generations as well as future generation of students in their community.   

In short, this grant has acted as a catalyst to create a positive impact on the university, the major, and in the lives of the students who were supported through it.

One of the lessons that the PI has learned (and the rest of the academic eco-system should understand) is that chief goal of these programs should be to ensure that the students graduate.   Ultimately, whether they met stringent standards or not is of far less importance.   In the end, graduation became the transformational event in their lives.  

More details on this projeect can be found in an ASEE paper published at the ASEE annual conference in 2022.  It was judged the best diversity paper within the technical section of Multidisciplinary Engineering and was nominated for the overall best diversity paper in the conference.
